channel.title: Flaws with java
channel.description:
list!
[s]preferably general flaws, stuff like security issues, rather than actual syntactical issues[/s]
any flaws at this point, are acceptable!

item.title: Flaws with java
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:34, topic:171864”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=231950.msg2045208#msg2045208 date=1202688796]

My only dislike about java is the fact that people can decompile bytecode.

People can decompile machine code as well, so that is not really a Java issue.
[/quote]

That’s not quite true. If you decompile native machine code, you only see the instructions and constants, not any other data (Like structures, or what programming langauge it was even written in). When you decompile a Java program, you get everything. Classes, interfaces, enumerations, I think some information about generics, constructors, etc.[/quote]

You can decompile native machine code into a higher level language as well, it may be easier with Java and there are already some tools written to do it, but it can still be done with native languages. It is not so much a Java problem as it is a problem common to all languages that don’t compile to machine code.

Read full topic

item.title: Flaws with java
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:33, topic:171864”][quote author=meiscooldude link=topic=231950.msg1985122#msg1985122 date=1199779597]
My only dislike about java is the fact that people can decompile bytecode.
[/quote]

People can decompile machine code as well, so that is not really a Java issue.[/quote]

That’s not quite true. If you decompile native machine code, you only see the instructions and constants, not any other data (Like structures, or what programming langauge it was even written in). When you decompile a Java program, you get everything. Classes, interfaces, enumerations, I think some information about generics, constructors, etc.

Read full topic

item.title: Flaws with java
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

meiscooldude:

My only dislike about java is the fact that people can decompile bytecode.

People can decompile machine code as well, so that is not really a Java issue.

BAsh(CntLgn):

I think java needs to drop some backwards compatibility.

I have to agree, it could be so much better if they just dropped a little backwards compatibility.

unlimitedorb:

2.) There doesn’t seem to be a true standard Tree data structure.

It is annoying that everything that is a storage structure HAS to implement the Collection interface, with some structures, such as trees, it just doesn’t fit.

Read full topic

item.title: Flaws with java
item.dc:creator: @Interdit Interdit
item.description:
@Interdit wrote:

Reflection undermines the entire Java Security Model

!

Read full topic

item.title: Flaws with java
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

There are only two things I have come across that I can gripe about with Java.

1.) Java’s implementation of Closure (Can you even call it that) i.e. anonymous inner classes is terrible.
2.) There doesn’t seem to be a true standard Tree data structure.

Other than that, I haven’t come across anything absolutely horrifying. Even the 2 I mentioned above aren’t earth shattering to begin with.

Read full topic

item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

I think java needs to drop some backwards compatibility.

item.title: Flaws with java
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

one thing about the constant pool is that longs and doubles take up two places, but UTF8 strings are much bigger then 8 bytes, and they only use one place?

i think the reason there is one class per file is so a classloader can find the class it needs using only the filename.

Read full topic

item.title: Flaws with java
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

I believe that classes could be able to be embedded in classes and that you can have multiple PUBLIC classes in the same source file (not as a sub package of the main class). This would reduce the file size as you would share the constant pool. Unfortunately it would break a lot of things. As for the context pool itself - I think its a good idea. It reduces size and everything is a simple lookup. Got a problem with reading that format? Use ASM or whatever library you want.

Read full topic

item.title: Flaws with java
item.dc:creator: @Silver_Lining Silver Lining
item.description:
@Silver_Lining wrote:

Hashtable. Also, Javacisnotrecognized is right. The class file format is fucking disgusting.

Read full topic

item.title: Flaws with java
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

There are no method datatypes. So if you want to implement any kind of callback, you need to create an interface, and a class that extends it. And they have to be in seperate files. So you wind up with hundreds of different files. That + horrible class file format = magnificently bad loading times.

Read full topic

item.title: Flaws with java
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:18, topic:171864”][quote author=Yz85Racer link=topic=231950.msg1985227#msg1985227 date=1199782165]
I don’t like it because it is ran on a vm.
[/quote]this is why i like java, however i dislike that they do not allow for a virtual filesystem[/quote]
Come to think of it, there is two sides to every story, even in this case. Running on a vm can be a good thing in ways, but bad in some other ways, e.g it does give up speed.

[quote=“meiscooldude, post:12, topic:171864”][quote author=Tree link=topic=231950.msg1985137#msg1985137 date=1199779890]

wow, silabsoft, how long have you been on mopar?

What has that got to do with anything. Another thing you managed to piss me off with was you complete cockiness when posting:

[quote]wow, … just wow… There is the door

First, client.java won’t compile (spell it right.)

second, its Javac not Jabbac, stands for Java Compiler. It means that you ar’nt pointing your batch code to the correct file.

And it is not Javas fault!!

LEARN TO SPELL[/quote]

There is a door, use it.

[/quote]

w/e it does’nt matter, Im sorry for getting a little cocky, just moparscape people kinda piss me off sometimes when they come in the wrong section[/quote]

I think it is quite obvious that I was playing with you, trying to get you to react.

second, its Javac not Jabbac, stands for Java Compiler. It means that you ar’nt pointing your batch code to the correct file.

And it is not Javas fault!!

LEARN TO SPELL
